SubTopics: Use a model to explain how the orbit of the Earth and sun cause observable patterns: a. day and night; b. changes in length and direction of shadows over a day.
Content: A student observes the shadow of a tree at two different times during the day.
problems/TN23G4S/media/1a.jpg
problems/TN23G4S/media/1b.jpg
Which of these causes the length and direction of the shadow to change?

A.Choice: the rotation of Earth on its axis

B.Choice: the amount of light given off by the sun

C.Choice: the distance between Earth and the moon

D.Choice: the revolution of Earth in orbit around the sun

SubTopics: Collect and analyze data from observations to provide evidence that rocks, soils, and sediments are broken into smaller pieces through mechanical weathering (frost wedging, abrasion, tree root wedging) and are transported by water, ice, wind, gravity, and vegetation.
Content: Students investigated how rocks change over time. The students used sugar cubes to model the rocks. The students put five sugar cubes into a plastic bottle. The students put the lid on the bottle and shook the bottle. The table shows the observations the students made.
problems/TN23G4S/media/2a.jpg
Which description of weathering is MOST similar to the way the rocks changed in the investigation?

A.Choice: Water in the cracks of a large rock freezes and expands, causing the rock to break apart.

B.Choice: Tree roots grow underneath a large flat rock, causing the rock to break into small pieces.

C.Choice: Fast-moving streams move rocks that then rub against each other, causing the rocks to change shape.

D.Choice: Animals dig into a rocky surface to make a den, causing the rock to crumble.

SubTopics: Obtain and combine information to describe that energy and fuels are derived from natural resources and that some energy and fuel sources are renewable (sunlight, wind, water) and some are not (fossil fuels, minerals).
Content: The table shows information about one renewable and one nonrenewable energy source.

:box:Energy from Wind

• The sun heats the ground.
• The ground heats the air above it.
• The heated air rises.
• Cool air rushes in to take the place of the air that rose.
• The energy from the moving air is captured by a wind turbine.

:box:Energy from Coal

• Plants receive energy from the sun.
• The plants die in a swamp.
• The plants are buried by many layers of sediment.
• Heat and pressure turn the plants into coal.
• Energy from coal is released by burning the coal.
Which statement correctly compares the energy from wind and the energy from coal based on the table?

A.Choice: Wind energy takes millions of years to form, but coal energy forms in a very short period of time.

B.Choice: Energy from wind and energy from coal both start as energy from the sun.

C.Choice: Wind is a source of stored energy, but coal is a source of kinetic energy.

D.Choice: Wind and coal both have to be burned to release the stored energy.

SubTopics: Use appropriate tools and measurements to build a model.
Content: A student is making a poster to display a diagram of Earth's layers. The table shows the student's plan for the thickness of each layer.
problems/TN23G4S/media/4a.jpg
The picture shows part of the student's diagram being measured with a meterstick.
problems/TN23G4S/media/4a.jpg
Which layer did the student draw correctly?

SubTopics: Determine the effectiveness of multiple solutions to a design problem given the criteria and the constraints.
Content: A city bridge was damaged. The city council plans to hire a company to replace the bridge. The bridge should be made out of concrete and steel so that it is strong enough for cars. It should take six months or less to build. The total cost should be less than $500,000.
The city council asks different companies to design a bridge for the project. The table shows each company's plans.
problems/TN23G4S/media/5a.jpg
Which company's plan BEST meets the needs of the city?

SubTopics: Develop models of terrestrial and aquatic food chains to describe the movement of energy among producers, herbivores, carnivores, omnivores, and decomposers.
Content: The table shows the roles of organisms in a food chain.
problems/TN23G4S/media/6a.jpg
Which diagram correctly shows how energy transfers in this food chain?

SubTopics: Develop and use models to determine the effects of introducing a species to, or removing a species from, an ecosystem and how either one can damage the balance of an ecosystem.
Content: Water chestnut is a plant that grows in ponds. The leaves float on the surface of the water. Water chestnut leaves grow fast and can cover the entire surface of the pond. This blocks sunlight from reaching other organisms in the pond. The picture shows some parts of a water chestnut plant.
problems/TN23G4S/media/7a.jpg
When water chestnuts begin to grow in a pond for the first time, which change will MOST LIKELY result?

A.Choice: More fish will live in the pond.

B.Choice: Fewer insects will visit the pond.

C.Choice: Populations of other plants in the pond will decrease.

D.Choice: Populations of different fish will come to live in the pond.

SubTopics: Obtain information about what a fossil is and ways a fossil can provide information about the past.
Content: Scientists think Tennessee was once covered by a shallow sea. Which fossil most likely led scientists to this conclusion?

SubTopics: Obtain information about what a fossil is and ways a fossil can provide information about the past.
Content: Scientists search for fossils in Antarctica. Antarctica has the coldest climate on Earth. The diagram shows a large rock with fossils that was found in Antarctica. The scientists use the key to identify the fossils in the rock.
problems/TN23G4S/media/9a.jpg
problems/TN23G4S/media/9b.jpg
Which conclusion should the scientists make based on these fossils?

A.Choice: Antarctica was once covered with water.

B.Choice: Antarctica is now covered with sandy soil.

C.Choice: Antarctica had a warmer climate at one time.

D.Choice: Antarctica now has many trees covering the landscape.

SubTopics: Use evidence to explain the cause and effect relationship between the speed of an object and the energy of an object.
Content: Students arrange plastic bottles as shown. The students roll a ball toward the bottles. The ball strikes the bottles and causes them to fall and roll to a new position. The arrows show how far each bottle rolls.
problems/TN23G4S/media/10a.jpg
Which statement makes an accurate claim about the bottles?

A.Choice: Bottle 1 has the least energy because it moves the shortest distance.

B.Choice: Bottle 5 has more energy than bottle 2 because it travels a farther distance.

C.Choice: Bottle 6 has the least energy because it moves the shortest distance.

D.Choice: Bottles 2 and 3 have the same amount of energy because they are located beside each other.
